thread.title: Legal Pot Sales to Exceed Cereal Sales in 2 Years
thread.title_full: Legal Pot Sales to Exceed Cereal Sales in 2 Years

author: Shoshanna Delventhal
title: Legal Pot Sales to Exceed Cereal Sales in 2 Years
text:
Legal Pot Sales to Exceed Cereal Sales in 2 Years By Shoshanna Delventhal | March 8, 2017 — 11:56 AM EST 
A recent report by Bloomberg analyst Kenneth Shea predicted that by 2019, U.S. sales of legal marijuana will reach a whopping $11.6 billion, outpacing ready-to-eat breakfast cereals with forecasted annual sales of $9.3 billion in two years. 
Behind the numbers is a story of a changing consumer preferences, a disrupted food industry and a booming marijuana market benefiting from rapidly easing regulations. Social Acceptance Drives Growth 
As state legislators vote in favor of marijuana, recreational and medical pot use continues to expand, raking in new tax streams while lifting the taboo associated with weed. On average, Millennials no longer view marijuana with the same stigma as other “drugs,” instead consuming the plant much like any other recreational product. Further, an aging population has turned to medical marijuana as an alternative to what’s been offered from the highly criticized pharmaceutical industry. As a result, across the country, pot sales are predicted to rise 29% annually until 2020. 
On the other hand, grown-up Millennials are shying away from the cereal of their childhood. Food industry giants such as General Mills Inc. ( GIS ) and Kellogg ( K ) have seen their sales dragged down by declining volumes of their cereal businesses. (See also: General Mills, Mondelez Eye 'Wellness' Millennials .) Long-Time Food Giants Struggle as Their Cereal Volumes Decline 
According Euromonitor data, total breakfast cereal volumes fell 2% in 2016. Despite food giants’ efforts to restructure and evolve to meet a new demand through new branding campaigns and recipe revisions, Euromonitor predicts volumes will continue to fall. Ultimately, the market research firm says traditional companies are failing to keep up with Millennial consumers who see cereal as “outdated” and “inconvenient.” 
By contrast, a recent Gallop report indicates that 19% of Americans from ages 18 to 29 say they “currently smoke” pot, higher than the estimated 13% of the total U.S. population. (See also: Kellogg's Tries a New Way to Promote Cereal .)
